title-group.article-title: Hygrothermal durability and failure modes of FRP for marine applications

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Sri Krishna Institute of Technology, Bangalore, India
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, University Viswesvaraiah College of Engineering, Bangalore, India
3Centre for Product Design and Manufacturing, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India
4School of Mechanical Engineering, University of Leeds, Leeds, UK

author-notes.corresp: M Raguraman, School of Mechanical Engineering, University of Leeds, Leeds, West Yorkshire, LS2 9JT, UK Email: r.munusamy@leeds.ac.uk

abstract.p: This article deals with the durability of 2D woven mat carbon/polyester, glass/isopolyester, and gel-coated glass/isopolyester reinforced composites under hygrothermic conditions with regard to marine applications. The test coupons were exposed to 60°C and 70°C at 95% RH for a maximum duration of 100 h. The samples were periodically withdrawn and weighed for moisture absorption and tested for the degradation in the mechanical properties such as ultimate tensile strength, flexural strength, interlaminar shear strength, and Young’s modulus and flexural modulus. Carbon/isopolyester-based specimens showed greater stability with respect to degradation in the mechanical properties than the glass/isopolyester/gel coat- and glass/isopolyester-based specimens. Glass/isopolyester exhibited the maximum moisture absorption, whereas the minimum moisture absorption was found in glass/isopolyester/gel coat. Diffusion coefficient (D) was found to be the highest for glass/isopolyester and the lowest for glass/isopolyester/gel coat, based on the Fick’s law of diffusion. Diffusion coefficient increases with the increase in temperature for all the specimens. Microstructure study of fractured specimens was carried out using scanning electron microscope to compare matrix/fiber debonding and matrix-degradation of fiber-reinforced polymer composites.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, fiber-reinforced composites were frequently used as engineering materials in structural parts of marine field such as ships, harbor facilities and floating structures, fishing trawlers, mine-hunting ships, canoes, and domes of submarines because of their favorable properties such as good corrosive resistance, high modulus and strength-to-weight ratio, good chemical stability, fatigue resistance, and easiness to make complex integrated structural parts.1 Generally, polymer-based materials are not water soluble but they are capable of absorbing various amounts of water, depending on their chemical nature and formulation, as well as on the humidity and temperature of the environment to which they are exposed. Water aging may strongly affect the matrix behavior, by producing changes in its chemical and physical nature, by itself or in conjunction with other chemical or physical agents such as heat and ultraviolet light.2,3 In humid temperature the water absorption rate increases with increase in temperature. In hot humid exposure, moisture diffuses through the fiber, matrix and fiber–matrix interface.4 The study of the interface between fiber–matrix regions was also important in determining the composite properties. The effects of moisture diffusion in polymers were Fickian and non-Fickian in nature. The type of non-Fickian diffusion shows that the viscoelastic nature of the polymer results in cracks. Carbon is more superior than glass with respect to moisture sorption. Iso polyester resins exhibit higher thermal and chemical stabilities in the case of moisture and therefore are the best option for use in marine applications.4 Moisture absorption leads to the reduction in the mechanical properties of the composite materials by degrading the fiber–matrix interfacial bond. The rate at which the moisture diffusion occurs in a composites depends on factors such as volume fraction of fiber, fiber orientation with respect to the direction of diffusion, type of fiber and matrix, voids, viscosity of matrix, humidity, and temperature.5 Under wet conditions, the glass/matrix interface is the determining factor of the reinforcement mechanism.6 The polymer matrix and the fiber/matrix interface can be degraded by a hydrolysis reaction of unsaturated groups within the resin.7–9 Debonding may occur at fiber/matrix interface.10 A concern with using carbon and glass fiber composites in marine structures is the limited understanding and small database of information of their long-term durability in hygrothermal environment. Furthermore, hygrothermal aging in the absence of external loads can lead to spontaneous formation of matrix microcracks in specimens.11 Temperature effect during humid aging on the interfaces of glass and carbon fiber-reinforced epoxy composites at higher temperature during hygrothermal aging not only increases the moisture uptake rate but it may also modify the local stress threshold required for delamination nucleation. Experiments were conducted on the effect of temperature on moisture absorption characteristics of carbon fiber/epoxy composites at 60°C temperature and 95% RH and also at 70°C temperature and 95% RH environments. Since the glass transition temperature (Tg) of isopolyester–glass composites is 116°C, it is decided that a maximum temperature range of 40% of Tg would be taken.12 Therefore, this study is conducted to report the results of the study on the effects of hygrothermal aging on water sorption and mechanical characteristics of glass/polyester, glass/polyester/gel coat, and carbon/polyester composite by exposing them to temperatures 60°C and 70°C and relative humidity 95% RH for a maximum duration of 100 h.

sec.title: Materials and processing
sec.p:
The trade names of the materials used for manufacturing the fiber–resin polymer-reinforced composites along with their mechanical properties as recommended by the supplier are given in Table 1. Three combinations of fiber–resin polymer-reinforced composites used in this study are glass fiber/isopolyester, glass fiber/isopolyester/gel coat, and carbon fiber/isopolyester. The specimens were fabricated using wet hand lay-up process of 2D woven mat fibers (0/90) and the number of fiber layers was derived based on the fiber/resin proportion 65/35 wt% in all the cases. Isopolyester resin, cobalt accelerator, and methyl ethyl ketone peroxide catalyst were procured from Bhilosa Tex N-Twist Pvt Limited, Mumbai, India. The specimens were naturally cured at room temperature for 2 weeks, before exposing them to hygrothermic conditions. Table 1.
Specifications of materials used
Materials Suppliers Density (gm/cc) Young’s modulus (GPa) Tensile strength (GPa)
Carbon fibers CS inter glass-Germany 1.82 230–240 4
Glass fibers Vetrotex, India 2.5 45–60 1.7–3.5
Isopolyester Bhilosa Tex N-Twist Pvt Limited, Mumbai, India 1.05 3.0 0.04

Experimental studies on the degradation of mechanical properties of ultimate tensile strength (UTS), flexural strength (FS), interlaminar shear strength (ILSS), Young’s modulus (E) and flexural modulus (FM) of the composites were carried out under hygrothemic conditions as per ASTM standards. The specimens were exposed to hygrothermic conditions at temperatures 60°C and 70°C at 95% RH for a period of 100 h. The specimens were periodically withdrawn, weighed for moisture absorption, and tested for mechanical property degradation; the failure mode of the FRPs was examined by the fractography using scanning electron microscopy (SEM).

sec.title: Hygrothermal test
sec.p:
The composite specimens of glass fiber/isopolyester, carbon/isopolyester, and glass fiber/isopolyester/gel coat had dimensions 50 × 6 × 3 mm3, 80 × 8 × 3 mm3, and 216 × 19 × 3 mm3 as per ASTM D 2344, ASTM D 760 and ASTM D 638 for inter-laminar shear, flexural and tensile strengths, respectively. These specimens were kept in the instrumented Environmental Chamber (M/s CM Environ systems, Bangalore) shown in Figure 1 at 95% RH at 60°C and 70°C for a maximum duration of 100 h. Figure 1.
Hygrothermic environmental chamber.

Specimens were withdrawn at regular intervals, the surface moisture was wiped, and they were then weighed in an electronic balance to monitor the change in behavior of mass or moisture diffusion. The percentage mass change (M) of the composite panel was computed by the expression13 (1) where ms is the mass of the panel after a given immersion time and md the original panel mass. The hygrothermic exposure is very critical for marine-grade polymer composites because it is an irreversible process. The moisture that the composite absorbs will cause degradation in the properties of the composites in a manner similar to that of accelerated aging.

sec.title: Ultimate tensile strength
sec.p: Specimens were tested for tensile strength using universal testing machine (UTM) at a cross-head speed of 1 mm/min and it is computed using the following formula (2) where UTS is the ultimate tensile strength (N/mm2), P the peak load (N), and A the cross-sectional area (mm2).

sec.title: Flexural strength
sec.p: The FSs of the specimen were determined using the three-point bending test with a span length of 90 mm using an instrumented 10-ton capacity UTM. The FSs of the composites were determined using the formula according to equation14 (3) where P is the peak load (N), L the support span length (mm), b the width of the specimen, and d the thickness of the specimen (mm).

sec.title: Interlaminar shear strength
sec.p: Three-point bend test was carried out to determine the inter-laminar shear strength using UTM at a cross-head speed of 1 mm/min. The average values have been reported. The inter-laminar shear was determined using the equation15 (4) where ILSS is the interlaminar shear strength (MPa), P the peak load (N), b the width of specimen (mm), and t the thickness of specimen (mm).

sec.title: Young’s modulus
sec.p: Young’s modulus is defined as the ratio of stress to strain within the elastic limit. It is determined using the equation (5) where σ is the stress (GPa), ε the strain, and E the Young’s modulus (GPa).

sec.title: Flexural modulus
sec.p: FM is defined as the ratio of stress to strain within elastic limit under three-point bending flexural using the formula (6) where P is the peak Load (N), L the length between supports (mm), B the breadth of the specimen (mm), D the depth of the specimen (mm), and δ the deflection at load ‘P’ (calculated within elastic limits).
Slope of P/δ is taken from the computer-generated graph for all specimens and used to calculate FM.

sec.title: Microstructural studies
sec.p: SEM was employed to characterize the tensile-fractured specimens before and after hygrothermic exposure. The type of damage that produces the degradation of a composite material has been typically classified as matrix damage (microcracks, coalescence of voids), fiber damage (breakage or buckling), or interface damage (debonding).16 Matrix mechanisms have been predominant in composites exposed to environmental conditions. Often, matrix cracking clears the way for other degradation mechanisms, which will eventually cause the composite to fail. Finally, the fiber–matrix interface failure has been difficult to detect and measure, quantitatively. Methods to characterize interfacial damage have been proposed by Jayamaran et al.17 The effect of the hygrothermic exposure on the interface region and the changes in the mechanical property were also studied through SEM.

sec.title: Results of moisture absorption
sec.p:
The effects of hygrothermic exposure on the percentage moisture absorption of carbon/isopolyester, glass/gel coat/isopolyester, and glass/isopolyester composites at 95% RH for 60°C and 70°C are shown in Figure 2(a) and (b), respectively. The maximum moisture absorption (M∞) values of the specimens at two temperatures are given in Table 2. The moisture absorption values were found to be 0.26% and 0.29% for glass/isopolyester, 0.21% and 0.24% for carbon/isopolyester, and 0.18% and 0.20% glass/isopolyester/gel coat at 60°C and 70°C and 95% RH, respectively. Maximum and minimum moisture absorption values were found in glass/isopolyester & glass/isopolyester/gel coat, respectively. Figure 2.
Moisture absorption vs. square root of time in hours at (a) 60°C and (b) 70°C at 95% RH. Table 2.
Maximum moisture absorption and diffusion coefficient values of the composites at 60°C and 70°C
Materials M∞ (wt%) at 95% RH Diffusion coefficient (m2/s) at 95% RH
60°C 70°C 60°C 70°C
Glass/isopolyester/gel coat 0.183 0.201 1.268 × 10−12 1.486 × 10−12
Carbon/isopolyester 0.213 0.241 1.566 × 10−12 1.638 × 10−12
Glass/isopolyester 0.26 0.29 1.803 × 10−12 2.043 × 10−12

sec.title: Diffusion studies
sec.p: The Fick’s Second law of diffusion was used to study the diffusion mechanism in polymer composites and the diffusion coefficient can be computed using the formula as per18 (7) where M1 and M2 are the moisture contents at times t1 and t2, respectively, h the thickness of the specimen, and M∞ the maximum moisture uptake. All fibers absorb less moisture compared to the polymeric matrix and may change the diffusion path of water molecules in an anisotropic fashion by hindering them from undergoing straight diffusion. Glass/isopolyester exhibited maximum diffusion coefficients 1.268 × 10−12 and 1.486 × 10−12, whereas glass/isopolyester/gel coat exhibited minimum diffusion coefficients 1.803 × 10−12 and 2.043 × 10−12 (Table 2) at 60°C and 70°C, respectively.

sec.title: Tensile strength
sec.p:
The change in tensile strength as a function of duration of exposure of the composite coupons to hygrothermic conditions is shown in Figure 3(a) and (b), respectively. Specimens after hygrothermic exposure show an increase in degradation, substantially with an increase in exposure of time. The percentage drops in UTS for carbon/isopolyester, glass/isopolyester/gel coat, and glass/isopolyester after 100 h of exposure were 14%, 25%, 28% and 16%, 27%, 32%, respectively. Carbon/isopolyester composite showed better tensile strength than glass/isopolyester and glass/isopolyester/gel coat. Figure 3.
Ultimate tensile strength vs. square root of time in hours at (a) 60°C and (b) 70°C at 95% RH.

sec.title: Flexural strength
sec.p:
All the three varieties of composites show degradation in FS after the hygrothermic exposure, as shown in Figure 4(a) and (b), respectively. Specimens after hygrothermic exposure show an increase in degradation substantially with the increase in the time of exposure. The percentage drops in FS for carbon/isopolyester, glass/isopolyester/gel coat, and glass/isopolyester after 100 h of exposure were 8%, 12%, 16% and 9%, 15%, 19%, respectively. Carbon/isopolyester composite showed better FS than glass/isopolyester and glass/isopolyester/gel coat. Figure 4.
Flexural strength vs. square root of time in hours at (a) 60°C and (b) 70°C at 95% RH.

sec.title: Interlaminar shear strength
sec.p:
The change in ILSS as a function of duration of exposure of the composite samples to hygrothermic conditions is shown in Figure 5(a) and (b), respectively. Specimens after hygrothermic exposure show an increase in degradation, substantially with an increase in exposure of time. The percentage drops in ILSS for carbon/isopolyester, glass/isopolyester/gel coat, and glass/isopolyester after 100 h of exposure were 6%, 8%, 11% and 7%, 9.3%, 13%, respectively. Carbon/isopolyester composite showed better ILSS than glass/isopolyester and glass/isopolyester/gel coat. Figure 5.
Interlaminar shear strength vs. square root of time in hours at (a) 60°C and (b) 70°C at 95% RH.

sec.title: Young’s modulus
sec.p:
The change in Young’s modulus as a function of duration of exposure of the composite specimens to hygrothermic conditions is shown in Figure 6(a) and (b), respectively. The specimens after hygrothermic exposure show increase in degradation substantially with increase in time of exposure. The percentage drops in Young’s modulus for carbon/isopolyester, glass/gel coat/isopolyester, and glass/isopolyester after 100 h of exposure were found to be 13.5%, 23%, 27% and 15%, 28%, 34% at 60°C and 70°C, respectively. Carbon/isopolyester composite showed better Young’s modulus than glass/isopolyester and glass/isopolyester/gel coat. Figure 6.
Young’s modulus vs. square root of time in hours at (a) 70°C and (b) 60°C at 95% RH.

sec.title: Flexural modulus
sec.p:
The change in FM as a function of duration of exposure of the composite specimens to hygrothermic conditions is shown in Figure 7(a) and (b), respectively. The specimen after hygrothermic exposure shows increase in degradation substantially with increase in time of 100 h. The percentage drops in FM for carbon/isopolyester, glass/isopolyester/gel coat, and glass/isopolyester after 100 h of exposure were found to be 8.5%, 13.5%, 17% and 9.6%, 16.5%, 20% at 60°C and 70°C, respectively. Carbon/isopolyester composite showed better FM than glass/isopolyester and glass/isopolyester/gel coat. Figure 7.
FM vs. square root of time in hours at (a) 60°C and (b) 70°C at 95% RH.

sec.title: Failure characterization of FRP by SEM
sec.p:
The scanning electron micrograph provides good evidence of the binding between the resin and the fiber before and after the hygrothermic exposure. During manufacturing of a composite, voids are introduced in the composites. This causes the theoretical density of the composite to be higher than the actual density. Also, the void content of a composite is detrimental to its mechanical properties. These include lower moisture resistance, shear stiffness and strength, compressive strength, transverse tensile strengths, and fatigue resistance.19 The microcracks and voids formed during the composite preparation can be traced using micrographs. The micrographs (Figure 8(a)–(c)) show that matrix/fiber bonding sustained after 100 h of exposure at 60°C in all three types of specimens and it was also observed that failure mode of fiber breakage is dominant in carbon/isopolyester compared to other specimens. At 70°C, micrographs (Figure 8(d)–(f)) of fractured specimens showed that fiber breakage as well as fiber pull-out and a higher degree of matrix degradation occur in glass/isopolyester specimens (Figure 8). Figure 8.
Micrographs of tensile-fractured carbon/isopolyester, glass/isopolyester/gel coat, and glass/isopolyester specimens at 60°C (a)–(c) and at 70°C (d)–(f), exposed for a duration of 100 h at 95% RH.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Hygrothermic behaviours of carbon/isopolyester, glass/isopolyester/gel coat, and glass/isopolyester composites were studied by exposing them to 60°C and 70°C and 95% RH in an environmental chamber for a maximum duration of 100 h. Diffusion coefficients were evaluated for all the test conditions. Moisture uptake in all test conditions showed that glass/isopolyester/gel coat specimens absorbed the least amount of moisture. Increase in temperature caused higher level of diffusion and hence the onset of saturation showed advancement in the number of hours of exposure to saturation. Consistently, all the specimens showed increase in the moisture uptake with respect to increase in temperature. The better performance of isopolyester was attributed to the gel coat which minimizes the voids and decreases water permeation.

Mechanical properties such as tensile strength, FS, ILSS, Young’s modulus and FM of carbon/isopolyester composites were well above those of the glass/isopolyester and glass/isopolyester/gel coat composites at all test conditions. Hence, it can be concluded that in terms of mechanical properties, carbon/isopolyester composites are superior even though they absorbed more moisture than glass/isopolyester/gel coat composites. Micrographs of fractured specimens of composites confirmed that matrix/fiber bonding sustained after 100 h of exposure at 60°C and 70°C.
